title: 115_hr2365
content:
The "Desert Community Lands Act" may be cited as the short title. Conveyance for Apple Valley Off-Highway Vehicle Recreation Area is addressed in the Act. The "Desert Community Lands Act" establishes definitions for Secretary and Town. It requires the Secretary of the Interior to convey approximately 4,630 acres of land to the town of Apple Valley, California for the Apple Valley Off-Highway Vehicle Recreation Area. The conveyance under this subsection is subject to valid existing rights and does not include the mineral estate. The land conveyed may be used by the Town for public purposes authorized in the Recreation and Public Purposes Act, including establishing an off-road vehicle recreation park for the public. The land conveyed to the Town may be used for off-road vehicle recreation, including races, events, and training. A designated area will discourage unauthorized off-highway vehicle use in environmentally sensitive areas. The Town cannot dispose of the land without approval from the Secretary. The Secretary of the Interior is required to convey land to the city of Twentynine Palms, California, without consideration, within a year of the enactment of the Act. The conveyance does not include the mineral estate and is subject to existing rights. Additionally, there is a provision for the conveyance of land to the city of Barstow, California. SEC. 4. CONVEYANCE TO CITY OF BARSTOW, CALIFORNIA.

The Secretary of the Interior must convey land to the city of Barstow, California, without consideration, within a year of the enactment of the Act. The conveyance excludes the mineral estate and is subject to existing rights. The Secretary of the Interior must convey land to the city of Victorville, California without consideration, within a year of the Act's enactment. The conveyance excludes the mineral estate and is subject to existing rights, with a reservation of a permanent easement for specified facilities. The easements granted to Pacific Gas and Electric Company allow for the construction, maintenance, and operation of public utility facilities, as well as the trimming of trees and brush deemed hazardous. The land must be kept free of buildings, structures, and wells.
